description: Fragment of a rectangular clay tablet, Neo-Assyrian.

notes.text: 1848,0720.121 = K.12398 = BM.139436, but only 1848,0720.121 has Smith’s pencil number. The tablet number is written on the reverse of 1848,0720.121, and Borger’s and Lambert’s transliterations confirms that K.12398 and BM.139436 have those numbers. Probably 1848,0720.121 is the original (copy by Layard), the other two are casts. [EJ]

description: Chronicle. Grayson, TCS 5, Babylonian Chronicle Fragment 3.

notes.text:
Farber 1980 (RV Grayson BHLT) 273: "ein Fragment, das möglicherweise zur 'Babylonian Chronicle Series' gehört ([...] In RlA 6 s.v. [s. oben.] wird unter Nr. 22a noch ein weiterer neu identifizierter und noch unpublizierter Chroniktext aus dem British Museum genannt. Ausserdem ist inzwischen nachzutragen Hunger, SpTU I Nr. 3 [Chronik für die Zeit Šulgis])."

Strassmaier: "Ein kleines Fragment siehe [Skizze] nur 6 Zeilenenden, und 9 Zeilenanfänge, siehe: [Kopie Kolumne ii'], Rückseite ganz weggebrochen . ."

framing:

description: Lexical; Ea?

notes.text:
Jursa (PIHANS 86: 5 sub 'Schultexte' within the 81-7-1 collection): “Schultexte: Manche Tafeln sind aufgrund von Kolophonen oder Merkmalen wie den typischen Reihen von Winkelhaken sofort als Schultexte zu erkennen. Sie liegen vor allem zwischen BM 42281 und BM 42929+ und in den oberen Nummern, nach BM 45410. Zweifellos gehören noch mehr der fragmentarischen literarischen und vor allem lexikalischen Texte hierher, die in denselben Bereichen (vor allem zwischen BM 42284 und BM 42936, BM 43336 und BM 43984 sowie ab BM 45418) zu finden sind und die aus Zeitmangel nicht genauer gesichtet werden konnten.”
--> Jursa mentions ranges of fragments, does not talk about this sepecific one, which in fact does not belong to a school tablet, but rather to a full MS of Sᵇ A [TM]

1'. [...] x# [...]

5'. [...] ana E₂ SI.SA₂ LU₂ NU KU₃ MUNUS NU KU₃# [(x) (x) NU] IGI#.BAR
#note: The duplicate in K.66 has nothing between the last KU₃ and the negated verb. There seems to be room for a couple of signs here or the scribe left a gap.
$ single ruling
6'. [...] DINGIR#-MEŠ ka-nu-ut be-[le]-e-ti
7'. [... tiz-qar?]-tu₂# ša₂-ru-uh-tu₂ i#-la₂#-a-ti
8'. [...]-MEŠ# bi-in-ti {d}+EN.LIL₂ ma-lik KUR-u₂ {d}i₂-gi₃-gi₃
9'. [... a]-ša₂#-ret-ti AN-e u KI-ti₃ ša₂ NU BAL-u qi₂-bit-sa
10'. [...] KUR ša₂-ki-nat nu-ri a-na DINGIR-MEŠ gim-ra-sun
11'. [... AN]-e# u KI-ti₃ mu-nam-mi-rat kib#-ra-a-ti
12'. [...]-at tu-qu-un-ti ša₂-lum-mat# šar#?-hat#? la-bi-šat ša₂-ru-ru
13'. [...]-de#?-e mu-šal-qa-ta li-ta ana# al#-lal-li {d}ŠU₂ qu-ra-di
14'. [...] {giš}GU.ZA u BAL-e ana ka-li-šu₂-nu LUGAL-MEŠ-ni
15'. [...] ta#-ha-zi mu-šak#-ṣi-rat a-nun-ti
16'. [... mu-kin?]-nat sah-maš-ti mu-tak#-ki-pat KUR-MEŠ-e
#note: The restoration follows Abusch and Schwemer 2011: 367 and note p. 371, where they offer the alternative, [šāki]nat.
17'. [...]-tu₂# a-bu-ub la ma#-har# a-li-lat tam-ha-ri
18'. [...]-la-at₂# mu-par-ri#-rat# ki-ṣir mul-tar-hi
19'. [...] ka#-ši-da-at la ma#-gi#-ri mu-hal-li-qat za-ʾ-i-ru₃
20'. [{d}a-num {d}+EN.LIL₂ u {d}]e#!-a DINGIR-MEŠ AD-MEŠ#-[ki] u₂#-šar-bu-u₂ be-lut-ki
21'. [...] x# u₂-šar-ri#-[hu MU-ki? u₂]-ša₂#-ti-ru man-za-[az]-ki#
22'. [...] x [x x x x]

#note: The LU is malformed.

@obverse
@column 1
1'. D[IŠ N]A su#-a#-lam# GIG# U₂# [BABBAR ...]
2'. NU# pa#-tan# EME#-šu₂ DAB#-bat NAG#-š[u₂ ...]
3'. A.MEŠ ina# {dug#}UTUL₂# ŠEG₆#-šal# GAZI#{sa[r} ...]
#tr.en: If a person is sick with mucus (suālu): [you pound] white plant, [crush it in filtered oil, honey and premium beer]. Without dining his tongue shall take it, you make him drink it, [make him vomit. And then] you boil water in a bowl, [you pound] mustard(kasû) [and make infusion into it. Without dining he shall drink it and then he will get better].
$ single ruling
4'. DIŠ NA MIN HENBUR₂# {u₂#}a#-ṣu-ṣu-u[m-ti ...]
5'. il#-lu#-ur# [GAZI]{sar#} HENBUR₂ {u₂}[x ...]
6'. HENBUR₂ {u₂#}UR#.TAL₂#.TAL₂# TEŠ₂.BI [SUD₂ ...]
7'. E₁₁-a NU pa-tan [NAG-šu₂-ma ...]
#tr.en: If a person, ditto: [you pound?] together shoots of aṣuṣumtu-plant [...] illūru-plant, [mustard(kasû)], shoots of [...] shoots of 'kid's ear'-plant (uzun lalê) [... You mix it in a liguid?, heat it up in an oven?] You take it out (of the oven). [You let him drink it] without dining [and he shall get better].
$ single ruling
8'. DIŠ NA su-a-lam GIG {u₂}NU.LU[H.HA ...]
9'. NU pa-tan N[AG ...]
#tr.en: If a person is sick with mucus (suālu): [you pound?] asafoetida(nuhurtu) [... mix in a liquid?] Without dining [you make him] drink [it and he will get better].
@reverse
@column 2

#tr.en: [...] one litre of premium beer. When it starts boiling [you take it out and ...] Afterwards, [he shall drink] one litre of sweet beer [...] and then at the apropriate time [...]
#note: Compare BAM 549 rev. ii 12ff. 
$ single ruling
5. DIŠ NA MIN {u₂}KUR.RA S[UD₂ ...]
6. DIŠ NA MIN {šim}LI S[UD₂ ...]
7. ina MUL₄ tuš-bat [...]
#tr.en: If a person, ditto (=is sick with mucus (suālu) and (excessive) saliva): you pound mint(ninû) [...]. If a person, ditto: you pound juniper(burāšu) [... you mix in in ...] you let it stay overnight under the stars [...]
#note: Compare BAM 549 rev. ii 16ff.
$ single ruling
8. DIŠ# NA# su#-alu u ha-h[a ...]
9. [...] x [...]
#tr.en: If a person is sick with mucus (suālu) and cough(hahhu) [... in water ...]

notes.text:
Obv. column 1 Prostration Hemerology; col. 1, 12 - col. 2 Exorcist's Almanac; rev. commentary on plant names (from the steppe) and other mat. med. Compare BM.37080 whose obv. is inscribed with Exorcist's Almanac and rev. with Uru.an.na sections. [HS]

See also under BM.39279 [HS]

atf:
@obverse
@column 1
1'. EME-šu₂# DAB-bat [...]
#tr.en: his tongue will take (the medication), [then he keeps on drinking it and will get better]
$ single ruling
2'. DIŠ NA MIN A u KAŠ ina ŠEN.TUR ŠEG₆-ša[l ...]
3'. lu sah-le₂-e pa-ṣa-te ana ŠA₃ ŠUB GAZ NU# p[a-tan NAG-ma TI]
#tr.en: If a person, ditto: you boil water and beer in a small coocking pot. You cruch into it [...] or crushed cress(sahlû). [He shall drink it without dining and get better].
$ single ruling
4'. DIŠ NA MIN qi₂-lip₂ ZU₂.LUM.MA KI I₃ ŠAH GE₆ x [...]
5'. NU pa-tan GU₇-šu₂ EGIR-šu₂ KAŠ LAL₃ bah-r[a ...]
6'. tu-ša₂-ʾ-ra-šu-ma ina IM.IM-a-bi u UD.DA tu-x [...]
#tr.en: If a person, ditto: [you crush?] date peel with fat of a black pig [...] he eats it without dining. Afterwards, [you let him drink] beer and boiling honey. You make him vomit [with a bird feather], you [...] the wind and the heat ...].
$ single ruling
7'. DIŠ NA MIN tuš-ka-a SUD₂ ana KAŠ.SAG ŠUB-di ina {im}ŠU.RIN.NA ta#-[x]
8'. ki-ma ip-ta-aš₂-lu₄ E₁₁-a LAL₃ u I₃ hal-ṣa ana ŠA₃ ŠU[B-di]
9'. lu ba-hi-ir ba-lu pa-tan NAG-šu₂ tu-šab-ra-šu₂-ma TI#
#tr.en: If a person, ditto: you pound tuškû-mineral, add it in premium beer, and [boil?] it in an oven. When it starts boiling you take it out and add into it honey and filtered oil. It should be boiling hot-without dining you make him drink it, let him vomit and he will get better.
$ single ruling
10'. DIŠ NA su-a-lam GIG U₂ BABBAR SUD₂ ina I₃ hal-ṣa LAL₃ u KAŠ.SAG GAZ
11'. NU pa-tan EME-šu₂ DAB-bat NAG-šu₂ tu-šab-ra-šu₂-ma
12'. A-MEŠ ina {dug}UTUL₂ ŠEG₆-šal GAZI{sar} SUD₂ ina ŠA₃ tara-bak NU pa-tan NAG-šu₂-ma TI
#tr.en: If a person is sick with mucus (suālu): you pound white plant, crush it in filtered oil, honey and premium beer. Without dining his tongue shall take it, you make him drink it, make him vomit. And then you boil water in a bowl, you pound mustard(kasû) and make infusion into it. Without dining he shall drink it and then he will get better.
$ end of column

@column 2
1'. x [...]
2'. ina x [...]
#tr.en: ... [...]  in ... [...]
$ single ruling
3'. DIŠ NA su-[a-lam GIG ...]
#tr.en: If a person [is sick] with mucus (suālu): [...]
$ end of column

@reverse
@column 1
$ broken

@column 2
1. {u₂}an-tah-še NU.LUH KAL.KU₇.KU₇ 3 U₂#.[HI.A ŠEŠ (...)]
2. TEŠ₂.BI ta-sak₃ KI LAL₃ u I₃.NUN₃ G[AZ? (x x x x)]
3. NU pa-tan GU₇-MEŠ-ma# [TI (...)]
#tr.en: antahšu-plant, asafoetida(nuhurtu), and kalgukku-mineral: these three drugs you pound together, crush them? in honey and ghee, he shall eat (the medication) without dining and [will get better].
$ single ruling
4. DIŠ NA ta-bi-lam u₂-sa-al ul ŠUB-a il₅-la-t[u ...]
5. ana TI-šu₂ {u₂}ur-ne₂-e A.GAR.GAR MAŠ.DA₃ TEŠ₂.BI SUD₂ ina KAŠ NU pa-tan# N[AG?-ma TI]
#tr.en: If a person has a dry cough, but cannot discharge (mucus) [...] his saliva [...] In order to heal this: you pound together unrnû-plant and gazelle droppings. He will drink (the medication) in beer, [and will get better].
$ single ruling
6. EN₂ su-a-lam MIN MIN da-ni ṣi-b[it-su]
#note: parallels for reconstruction in Collins, MedIncantation, pp. 260f.
7. ina bi-rit ha-še-e it-ta-di {geš}GU.ZA-šu₂ at-lak su-alu ul# [šu-bat-ka]
8. ša₂ ki-ṣir-ti gu-uh-ha u s[u-alu]
9. {d}gu-la be-let TI.LA lip-pu#-la# šur#-ši#-[ka TU₆.EN₂]
#tr.en: Incantation: O suālu, suālu, suālu. Strong is his grip. He set up his throne midst of the lungs. Go away, this is not your [dwelling]! Of the constriction, coughing, and mucus(suālu), may Gula, mistress of health destroy your roots! [Incantation spell].
$ single ruling
10. KA.INIM.MA [DIŠ NA su-alu GIG.GA.KAM₂]
#tr.en: It is an invocation [for the case when a person is sick with suālu?]
$ single ruling
11. DU₃#.DU₃#.BI# ana# UGU# x [...]
#tr.en: Its medical application: [you ...] on top of [...].
$ single ruling
12. DIŠ NA su-a-lam u UH₂ [...]
13. 10 GIN₂# {u₂#}IN.NU.UŠ x x [...]
14. ŠEG₆-šal ki-ma ib-ta#-[aš₂-lu ...]
15. EGIR-šu₂ 1 SILA₃ KAŠ DU₁₀.GA NAG# š[u₂ ...]
#note: Compare BAM 550 iv 1'ff.
#tr.en: If a person [is sick] with mucus (suālu) and (excessive) saliva [...] you boil ten shekel of maštakal-plant ... [... one litre of premium beer]. When it starts boiling [you take it out and ...]. Afterwards, he shall drink one litre of sweet beer [... and then at the apropriate time ...].
$ single ruling
16. DIŠ NA MIN {u₂}KUR.RA SU[D₂? ...]
17. DIŠ NA MIN# {šim}LI G[I ...]
18. ina M[UL₄ tuš]-bat [...]
#note: Compare BAM 550 iv 5'ff.
#tr.en: If a person, ditto (=is sick with mucus (suālu) and (excessive) saliva): you pound mint(ninû) [...]. If a person, ditto: [you pound] juniper(burāšu) and reed [... you mix in ...] you let it stay overnight under the stars [...].
$ single ruling
19. DIŠ# NA s[u?-alu u ha]-h[a GIG ...]
20. [x x] ina# A.MEŠ [...]
#tr.en: If a person [is sick with mucus (suālu) and cough(hahhu) ... in water ...].
$ single ruling
$ rest of side broken

atf:
@column 1'
1'. [...] x TI-qe₂
2'. [... ina I₃].GIŠ SUD₂
3'. [... N]U KUD-as
#tr.en: . . . you take . . . you pound it in oil . . . it cannot be removed.
$ single ruling
4'. [x x x x x x x x x x x x x x IGI-MIN-šu₂ MU]D₂ u₂-kal-la
#note: Compare Cranium 1, BAM 480 ii 12-15.
5'. [x x x x x x x x x x x SI]LA₁₁-aš LAL
6'. [x x x x x x x x x x A.GEŠTIN.N]A SILA₁₁-aš KIMIN
7'. [x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x G]A SILA₁₁#-aš# KIMIN#
#tr.en: If a man’s cranium has fever, and consequently his eyes flicker (and) contain blood: you crush (and) sieve a third of a litre of @i{saḫlû} ('cress'), you knead it in juice from @i{kasû}-herb ('tamarind') (and) you bandage him (with the mixture). You knead a third of a litre of @i{saḫlû} ('cress') (and) a third of a litre of @i{isqūqu} (a type of groats) in vinegar (and) DITTO (= you bandage him with the mixture). You knead a third litre of leaves from @i{tittu}-tree ('fig tree') in milk (and) DITTO (= you bandage him with the mixture). You knead a third of a litre of @i{būšānu}-plant ('smelly disease' plant) in milk (and) DITTO (= you bandage him with the mixture).
$ single ruling
8'. [x x x x x x x x IG]I.MIN-šu₂ i#-bar#-ru-ra
#note: Compare Cranium 1, BAM 480 ii 19-20, as well as BAM 3 i 20-21.
9'. [x x x x x x x x x {šim}L]I {šim}GAM.MA {šim}BULUH
10'. [x x x x x x x x x x in]a GA SILA₁₁-aš LAL-ma DIN-uṭ
#tr.en: If a man’s cranium is inflamed with sun-heat, and consequently his eyes flicker (and) . . .: you knead boiled @i{tuḫḫū} ('bran'), @i{burāšu}-aromatic (a kind of juniper), @i{ṣumlalû}-aromatic, @i{baluḫḫu}-aromatic ('ferula gummosa'), @i{saḫlû} ('cress'), @i{kupsu} (‘sesame pomace’) (and) @i{sīḫu}-plant ('wormwood') in milk, you bandage him with the mixture, and then he will recover.
$ single ruling
11'. [...] x ina UD.1.KAM₂ ša₂ {iti}BARA₂
12'. [...] {sig₂#}HE₂?#.MED#?.DA#? NU#.NU
#tr.en: . . . you spin together red wool . . .

@column 2'
1'. id-ra SUD₂?# [...]
#tr.en: you pound(?) @i{idru} ('saltpetre') . . . 
$ single ruling
2'. {šim}GUR₂.GUR₂ {ši[m} ...]
3'. ZI₃ GIB₃ DIDA x [...]
#tr.en: @i{kukru}-aromatic . . . flour from @i{kibtu} ('wheat'), @i{billatu} ('beerwort') . . .
$ single ruling
4'. {šim}GUR₂.GUR₂ {ši[m} ...]
5'. ZI₃ GIB₃ ŠI[KA? ...]
6'. DIŠ-niš ina KAŠ S[AG? ...]
#tr.en: @i{kukru}-aromatic . . . flour from @i{kibtu} ('wheat'), sherd(?) . . . together in prime-quality(?) beer . . .
$ single ruling
7'. DIŠ# NA# SAG#.DU#-su G[IG-MEŠ x x x x (x x x)]
#note: Compare Cranium 4, CT 23 50 i 7-11. 
8'. zap-pi₂ ŠAH MUN [x x x x x x x x x x x x]
9'. SAR-ab I₃.GIŠ Š[EŠ₂ x x x x x x x x x x x x x x]
10'. ZI₃ MUNU₆ ZI₃.KUM GIR₃.PAD.D[U x x x x x x x x x x]
11'. GUR-ma an-nu-ha-r[a x x x x x (x x x)]
12'. DIŠ-niš BIL-lu MAR ina [x x x x x x x x x x]
13'. A.GEŠTIN.NA BIL.L[A₂ x x x x x x (x x x)]
14'. IM#.GU₂#.EN#.NA# [x x x x x x x (x x x)]
#tr.en: If a man's head is full of sweet lesions: you parch pig bristle, salt, @i{isqūqu} (a type of groats) (and) sheep bone, you shave his head, you anoint it with oil (and) you scatter (the drugs over the anointment). You anoint (his head) with oil, you pound @i{šammu peṣû}-plant ('white plant') (and) you scatter it (over the anointment). You dry, crush (and) scatter root from @i{irrû} ('cucumber') (over his head). You parch (and) pound flour from @i{buqlu} ('malt'), @i{isqūqu} (a type of groats) (and) sheep bone together (and) you scatter them (over his head). You roast (and) pound repeatedly  @i{annuḫaru} (a mineral) (and) @i{gabû} ('alum') together, you keep anointing (his head) with oil (and) you scatter(?) them (over the anointment). You roast (and) scatter . . . (over his head). You anoint (his head) with sour vinegar, you pound @i{nīnû} ('mint') (and) you scatter it (over the anointment). You knead river mud in juice from @i{suluppū} ('date') (and) you bandage him (with the mixture).

#tr.en: Palace of Ashurbanipal, king of the universe, king of the land Aššur, on whom Nabû and Tašmētu (gods of writing) have bestowed wisdom. He (i.e. Ashurbanipal) acquired for himself shining eyes the pinnacle of scholarship. Of the kings who came before me, none were able to comprehend these tasks. Medical prescriptions from head to toenail (i.e. the Nineveh Medical Encyclopaedia), other selections, clever learnings, (and) whatever pertains to the great medical knowledge of Ninurta and Gula (gods of healing), I have written on tablets, checked, collated and deposited them in the middle of my palace (i.e. Nineveh) for my reading and recitation.’

description: Fragment of a clay tablet, 8 lines of inscription. Neo-Assyrian.

notes.text:
1'-3'? // ACh. Supp. 2 no. 1a iv 32-33
